title: What percentage of soldiers fired their weapons in WW2? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know for a fact in the American Army that just about all of them had to qualify, so I would suppose that nearly all of the soldiers who were taken into the military had to fire some sort of gun at some point. As to combat, I understand the figures are approximately 20 to 1 , that is, that for every soldier that you get into combat, there is that many support people behind that single soldier. Most soldiers in combat would at some point or other have had to fire their gun, or work whatever team weapon they were assigned to ( tank,mortar, howitzer, medium or heavy machine gun, Naval gun, Etc), so all soldiers in combat have to do something concrete-- to, at the very least, keep from being defeated if not actually triumph. So, just about every World War II gun that had been issued has been fired by the soldier was issued to. As for those that were carried into combat, most of them were fired in the general direction of somebody who did not like them. Bear in mind that a great many weapons were still in quartermaster stocks at the end of World War II, so there's a fair number of these guns that were eventually sent elsewhere in mint condition-- that is, unfired.

I cannot speak for other nations, by near the end of the war, a survey of US army soldiers revealed that, of the combat infantrymen who had actually been in combat, only about 1/3rd had actually fired their m-1 rifle in combat. Crew served weapons (BAR’s, machine guns, etc. had much much higher participation rates.

Varies. I think America had 9(?) soldiers in the supply chain for every 1 combatant…Japan, 1 to 1..…...others, various ratios... and differed at different times and places…e.g. Bastonge v Pensacola. Hard, if not impossible to answer accurately.
